newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigera orders massive fuel import to end crisis.
newsitem.headline: Nigera orders massive fuel import to end crisis.

text.p: Oil-producing Nigeria announced on Tuesday that it had ordered the immediate importation of 33 cargoes of petroleum products to end an acute fuel shortage in the country.

"The cargoes will come from Europe, especially Spain as well as other African countries," Ibrahim Abubakar, the managing director of the Pipelines and Products Marketing Company (PPMC), a unit of the Nigerian National Petroleum Corp (NNPC) told reporters in Lagos.
Abubakar said of this, 24 cargoes would be petrol (PMS), five cargoes would be kerosene (ATK) including aviation fuel and four cargoes would be diesel (AGO).
The importation followed crisis talks by Nigeria's military rulers in the capital Abuja on Monday over the fuel crunch that has paralysed businesses and caused severe hardship for commuters.
"Starting from today, 24th June, 1997, we shall have in our system for distribution in Lagos, Ore, Ilorin and Ibadan depots over 120,000,000 litres of PMS," Abubakar said.
He said the first consignment of 30,000 metric tonnes of fuel would arrive in Nigeria at 10 p.m. (2100 GMT) on Tuesday and others would arrive on Friday and Sunday this week.

Abubakar said military ruler General Sani Abacha had also approved an immediate realistic reassessment of Nigeria's four refineries and pipelines in order to make funds available for their rehabilitation.
"At the moment, discussions are on with internationally acclaimed consultants who will undertake the reassessment of the refineries and the pipelines," he said.

Nigeria pumps about two million barrels per day of crude oil daily and has four oil refineries with a nameplate capacity of 445,000 bpd but in reality they produce well below that because of their deteriorating state.
